Authors:
Ya-Ping Chen, Turginov Orzimat Turdimatovich, Maxim S.
Nuraliev, Predrag Lazarević, Bryan Drew, CHUNLEI XIANG
Title:
Biogeography, diversification, and taxonomy of the northern
temperate genus Dracocephalum s.l. (Lamiaceae)
Abstract:
The arid Asian interior (Central/and West Asia) and the
Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP) are both global biodiversity hotspots. A
close relationship between the floras of the two regions has been
suggested, but patterns of biogeographical connections between them are
poorly understood. The genus Dracocephalum is most diverse in the
steppe-desert biomes of the Asian interior and the alpine region of the
QTP, making the genus an ideal group to explore the biogeographical
connections between the Asian interior and QTP. Using a total of 66 taxa
comprising more than 80% of extant Dracocephalum species, we
investigated the evolutionary history of Dracocephalum by performing
morphological, phylogenetic (maximum parsimony, likelihood and Bayesian
inference based on nuclear ITS and ETS, plastid rpl32-trnL, trnL-trnF,
ycf1, ycf1-rps15, and two low-copy nuclear [AT3G09060 and AT1G09680]
markers), divergence time, and ancestral range estimation analyses. The
genus originated in Central/West Asia and southern Siberia around 16.32
(10.9821.99) Ma and dispersed from Central/West Asia into the QTP region
twice independently during the Pliocene. The aridification of the Asian
interior promoted the rapid radiation of Dracocephalum within this
region, and the uplift of the QTP appears to have triggered the
dispersal and recent rapid diversification of the genus in the QTP and
adjacent regions. All analyses indicated that Hyssopus and Lallemantia
should be included within Dracocephalum. Thus, we propose a broadly
circumscribed Dracocephalum divided into nine sections based on
molecular phylogenetic and morphological evidence.
